content.body: TabAtkins: FWIW, it's really when you invoke https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-url-parser that you don't pass a third argument
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: FWIW, it's really when you invoke https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-url-parser that you don't pass a third argument

content.body: ...oh, huh, I think I finally understand. I didn't realize URLs were, by definition, made of ASCII and percent-encoded bytes; I assumed that after parsing they were codepoints.
TabAtkins: they are code points, just all of them are ASCII :-)
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: they are code points, just all of them are ASCII :-)

content.body: right, I mean non-ascii codepoints are turned into ascii codepoints via %-encoding, as part of the underlying value of the URL
TabAtkins: I kinda redundantly left that remark in the issue as well for other onlookers as well as that we're experimenting with this in WebKit
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: I kinda redundantly left that remark in the issue as well for other onlookers as well as that we're experimenting with this in WebKit

content.body: rather than as a late "serialize this URL" step
Yeah makes sense. One of those things we might do differently if it were designed today.
